newsitem.title: USA: AMP sees pressures on Q4, consolidation.
newsitem.headline: AMP sees pressures on Q4, consolidation.

text.p: AMP Inc said on Wednesday that "significant price erosion" personal computers and communications has taken a greater than expected toll on its gross margins, exerting pressure that will probably continue into the fourth quarter.

The company said that prognosis may ultimately lead to consolidation of some of its underperforming businesses and "more aggressive improvement of manufacturing efficiencies to better realign our costs with revenues," AMP Chief Executive and President William Hudson said in a statement.
Hudson said that going into the year, the company expected sales growth to be "rather modest" in the first part of the year before strengthening in the second half.
However, key industries, such as personal computer and communications areas softened, serving as a drag on automotive and consumer/commercial segments that were deemed "strong."
The 1996 fiscal year year, he said, "has turned out to be an exceptionally challenging experience."
"We continue to take decisive actions to reduce manufacturing costs and cut expenses to align more realistically with actual sales," he added.
"However, it is clear we must increase our efforts to both accelerate growth and reduce costs and expenses to offset price reductions."

When the consolidation and cost cutting measures are implemented, "the effects will increase 1997 financial returns and enhance the prospects of AMP to continue its leadership in global markets," Hudson said.

The company said it also is determined to expand geographically, diversify its product and market mix and make "significant" investment in research and development and engineering for new products and processes.
For the third quarter, the company reported net income of $94.8 million, or $0.43 per share, compared with $110.7 million, or $0.51 per share, for the same period in the prior year.
AMP said the earnings per share of $0.43 were "slightly below" earlier expectations because of the greater than expected price erosion.
In mid-September, it had lowered expectations to between $0.45 and $0.50 per share.
